thread.title: UKIP collapse as party loses almost every council seat in the local election

author: Simon Meechan
title: UKIP collapse as party loses almost every council seat in the local election
text:

UKIP has lost almost all of its council seats leading to its former chairman openly discussing the possible end of the party.
A total of 44 UKIP candidates’ seats were contested in the local elections, but the party lost almost all of them.
As of 9am, UKIP lost 43 council seats, held one in Derby and gained another in the East Midlands city. It now has three councillors in Derby, as not all of the city’s seats were contested.
In the North East, it did not even field candidates in Sunderland and has failed to win any seats in Newcastle or South Tyneside. Gateshead and North Tyneside’s results will be called later this morning. UKIP leader Gerard Batten (Image: PA)
The results are a huge contrast to the party’s 2014 high point, when it took 17% of the vote and 166 council seats, as calls ramped up for the EU referendum which led to Britain voting to leave the bloc. Read More Local election results: Newcastle, Sunderland and South Tyneside elections at a glance
The collapse comes a year after UKIP lost 114 of its 115 county council seats in the previous local elections.
Former deputy chairman Suzanne Evans has admitted the Euro sceptic party could “crumble” - although at the same time hailed UKIP as “one of the most successful political parties in history”. UKIP Health spokesperson Suzanne Evans (Image: Getty Images Europe)
She said: “I have to say, three councillors in Derby, one of them actually unseating the leader of the Labour council, it might not be UKIP’s night but my goodness me when we do win we do it with style and we really put the cat among the pigeons.”
She added: “If UKIP does crumble I think you could still arguably make the case that it’s been one of the most successful political parties in history.” Read More Newcastle City Council local elections 2018 results IN FULL - how every candidate scored
The demise could be because post-Brexit referendum, voters think UKIP’s purpose has been served.
Other factors could be new leader Gerard Batten’s impact. Mr Batten sparked controversy with his views about Islam’s influence on Britain. Like us on Facebook
